at LinkedIn I have been working on messaging for some time now one of the aspects of instant messaging
that makes it challenging is that users interact with each other in real time
so this is not too big of an issue when users are being served by the same Data Center
but this becomes a significant Challenge and users are interacting with each other and are routed to completely
different data centers because of their Geographic locations
so imagine Alice from the US sends a message to Jane in Australia
and they're pinned to different data centers
in a naive implementation Alice would write the message to Jane's mailbox in
her own data center in the US
this message would then eventually get replicated to change data center in
Australia
and Jane would see the message only when the replication finishes and this
replication can take multiple seconds
as you can see this naive cross data center replication strategy doesn't work too well for instant messaging
apart from LinkedIn messaging I started noticing that other products and services across LinkedIn were running
into a very similar problem when they were trying to build a live interaction with each other across
multiple data centers at this time we were also building products like live video we were doing
events live audio rooms and it seemed like a pretty Universal problem for such
experiences now this is obviously a very challenging
technical problem that we had to solve so I started applying the framework that I shared with you
many teams were complaining about a lack of a strategy to address this issue
people were resorting to brute force solutions instead of a common solution in our infra layer
scope of the problem was clearly Beyond messaging sure we could have solve it only for messaging but there was clear
scope for this problem to be solved more genetically and it clearly mattered to the business
as we would not really have been able to ship all these important product experiences without a solution to this
problem or maybe we would do so with expensive individual Solutions at the application
there and so it had all the right ingredients for a problem that needed to be
addressed with a common solution for the large engineering organization
so next I evaluated the skills I need to solve this problem
this problem I obviously needed many technical skills like understanding cross data center
routing at LinkedIn understanding cross data center replication in our data layer
understanding Atomic commit protocols on databases and doing trade-offs between latency and

source Solutions or build something in-house now these are all great skills to pick
up for a systems engineer to grow to a stop loss role
but even more than that I needed many of the same soft skills that I mentioned earlier
Gathering requirements from other teams with the same problem building a business case for solving

infrastructure connecting the work to business impact across application teams
and gaining alignment with storage infrastructure leads and executives
and of course to do all of this I needed to describe the problem and propose solution with clear written technical
communication now you may wonder whether all this

messaging but such problems give you that opportunity to broaden the scope of your
impact and solve this problem not just for your team but for similar use cases

common libraries to Route traffic to objects and entities pinned to a certain Data Center

now let's go through one more technical example where I encountered a problem I recognized a pattern and built a genetic
solution which is now widely used at LinkedIn
so going back to my work on LinkedIn messaging this diagram represents a very simple
view of the message and delivery flow a sender sends a message the messaging
server does some pre-processing to authorize the send and then the message is persisted in the backend
finally after persistence the message is delivered to the recipient device
now if the pre-processing fails we simply return a forexx response to the client
and if the message passes that step a payload is passed to the persist message operation
and a two or two is returned to the client now the reason for that is that the persist message operation can possibly
take longer and we don't want the client to wait for that to complete
now the challenge with this flow is that the persist operation can fail and we can't really expect the client to
retry for these server failures so we need to make sure that the persist message operation completes reliably
once we send back the 202 accepted to the client it's now the server's responsibility to
finish persisting the message that the sender sent
this is where we realized that we need a durable queue which can queue up these
persist operations so that when we process these operations and do it
asynchronously we reliably complete them
and we also realized that this circle part of the flow is actually pretty
generic so we built this generic solution for
Reliable processing of queued operations where a job processor is responsible for
completing these operations and retrying any operations that fail so that we never lose any individual operation
and going back to our theme this needed
I need to build a solution with strict requirements I needed exponential backup with retries I needed durability of the
operations across deployments and failures and I need to evaluate various open
source and enough solutions for an asynchronous operation queue and job processor
now these were all invaluable technical skills to pick up
and even more importantly this pattern of reliable async processing needed a
generic solution for many other problems elsewhere in the company we needed it for asyn completion of
large bulk operations from from end users like like gdpr data export
and for operations that needed 100 reliability like Payment Processing so building this solution generically
gave me an opportunity to have an impact on teams outside my organization that I
